Chapter 20: The Siege of Loja

Date: May 30, 1431 (Morning)
Location: Siege camp outside Loja fortress

Dawn breaks gray and cool over the Genil valley. You wake to the sounds of a military camp stirring to life—thousands of men coughing, speaking in low voices, the clatter of cookpots and the whinny of horses being fed. Your tent sits on a low rise perhaps half a mile from Loja's walls, close enough to see the fortress clearly in the morning light but beyond effective bowshot.

Through the tent opening, you can see Loja perched on its height. The fortress looks formidable in the pale dawn—thick Moorish walls of reddish stone, towers at intervals, banners flying defiantly. The town spreads below the castle proper, also walled, perhaps eight hundred buildings clustered tight. Smoke rises from morning fires within. They're watching you just as you watch them.

Captain Fernán appears at your tent. "Your Majesty. Master Calabrese requests audience when you're ready—he's been surveying positions for the bombards since first light. The Master of Calatrava also wishes to discuss the siege lines." He pauses. "And there's news from a scout patrol that returned an hour ago. They found something... unusual. Bodies. Moorish raiders, they think, but the manner of death is strange. Don Rodrigo is examining them now."

The camp bustles with purposeful activity. Work parties are already cutting timber for siege works. The bombards sit on their carriages near the artillery park, massive and patient. Your army, though tired from the march, is settling into the grim business of siege warfare. This will take weeks, and everyone knows it.

Don Rodrigo de Perea arrives quickly, still wearing his riding boots caked with mud from the patrol. He's a lean man in his thirties, one of the scouts who'd proven himself during the march to Loja—sharp-eyed and methodical. He bows briefly, then gestures for two of his men to bring forward several items wrapped in cloth.

"Your Majesty, we found them about three miles north, in a ravine off the main road to Granada. Seven bodies, all Moorish. At first we thought they'd been caught by one of our patrols, but..." He unwraps the cloth to reveal weapons—distinctly Moorish scimitars and daggers, still bloodied. "They killed each other, Sire. The wounds match these blades, not our swords. And look at this."

He lays out clothing and insignia from the bodies. "These three wore the green sash of Granada's regular forces—local men, probably from the city itself. But these four..." He indicates different cloth, rougher weave, different colors. "North African. Berber tribal patterns, likely from the Sultan's Maghrebi reinforcements. The wounds suggest the Granadans attacked the Berbers, or perhaps the other way—hard to say who started it. But it was vicious. Close combat, personal. This wasn't battle confusion. This was murder between allies."

He pauses, meeting your eyes. "There's more, Your Majesty. We found tracks suggesting a larger group was there—perhaps twenty men total. The survivors fled in different directions. North toward Granada, and east toward the mountains. They split apart after the killing."

The morning sun slants through your tent opening. Don Rodrigo awaits your response, the bloody evidence laid out before you.

And the Granada locals probably resent sharing command with outsiders." He gathers the evidence. "Shall I send riders to see if we can capture any of those who fled? They might talk, especially if they're angry at their former comrades."

You follow him outside into the brightening morning. The camp sprawls across the valley floor—thousands of tents, picket lines of horses, supply wagons in neat rows. Calabrese leads you to the northern edge of the camp where your five medium bombards wait.

"We have two good positions, Sire." He points toward Loja with a gnarled finger. "See there—that ridge, four hundred yards from the main gate? Solid ground, good angle of fire, close enough for accuracy. I can put three bombards there to hammer the gatehouse and the wall sections on either side. It's within their bowshot, so we'll need mantlets and gabions for the gun crews."

He turns, indicating a second rise to the east. "And there—that hillock overlooks the town's eastern wall where it's thinnest, near the postern gate. Two bombards there can breach that section while the three at the main gate keep the defenders' heads down. Classic two-point bombardment."

He pauses, his expression turning serious. "But Your Majesty, the bombards are tired from the march. The barrels need inspection for cracks, the carriages need repair, and we're low on quality powder—the rough jostle on the road settled the ingredients poorly. I need two days minimum to make everything ready, three would be better. Rush it, and we risk a barrel bursting."
